item.title: Soccer Star
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: This magazine that was originally named after a great footballer, and was launched as Raich Carters Soccer Star in 1952 and dropped the Raich Carter title 3 years later in 1955, reverting to the simple title Soccer Star. Between 20 September 1952 and 19 June 1970 it ran for an amazing 936 issues. The issues […]
item.content:encoded:
This magazine that was originally named after a great footballer, and was launched as Raich Carters Soccer Star in 1952 and dropped the Raich Carter title 3 years later in 1955, reverting to the simple title Soccer Star.

Between 20 September 1952 and 19 June 1970 it ran for an amazing 936 issues.

The issues werent numbered in the same way as most other magazines, they used a volume based format with a season by season numbering system with 52 weekly issues.
It was a newspaper type publication with the majority of its content being in plain black and white, in fact it wasn’t until the late 60’s that they included full colour front and back pages.
Many believe the beginning of the end for the Soccer Star was the introduction to the football magazine market in 1967 of Jimmy Hills Football Weekly, however it managed to continue until 1970 when it was incorporated into World Soccer which had been running since 1960

Soccer Star 1961-02-18
Soccer Star 1961-03-04
Soccer Star 1961-03-25
Soccer Star 1961-08-12

item.title: World Soccer
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: World Soccer is an English-language football magazine, published by Kelsey Media. The magazine was established in 1960 and is the oldest continually published football magazine in the United Kingdom. It specialises in the international football scene. Its regular contributing writers include Brian Glanville, Keir Radnedge, Sid Lowe and Tim Vickery. World Soccer is a member […]
item.content:encoded:
World Soccer is an English-language football magazine, published by Kelsey Media. The magazine was established in 1960 and is the oldest continually published football magazine in the United Kingdom. It specialises in the international football scene. Its regular contributing writers include Brian Glanville, Keir Radnedge, Sid Lowe and Tim Vickery. World Soccer is a member of the European Sports Magazines (ESM), an umbrella group of similar magazines printed in other languages. The members of this group elect a European “Team of the Month” and a European “Team of the Year”.

Since 1982, World Soccer has also organised “Player of the Year”, “Manager of the Year” and “Team of the Year” awards.

The magazine was first published in London in October 1960, by Echo Publications. The first edition featured an image of Titus Buberník and Svatopluk Pluskal on the front cover. It was edited by Robert Bolle, with Graham Payne, editor of weekly sister publication Soccer Star, as features editor; Jack Rollin, who later edited The Football Yearbook for many years, as home editor; and Eric Batty as overseas editor. Batty, who later edited the magazine, published an annual World XI from 1960 to 1992. Brian Glanville has written a column for the magazine since April 1963. In 1970, Soccer Star, which was first published on 20 September 1952 as Raich Carter’s Soccer Star, was incorporated into World Soccer. Keir Radnedge, who had been associate editor, took over from Philip Rising as editor in the late 1980s and was replaced by deputy editor Gavin Hamilton in January 1998 and became executive editor. Radnedge continues to have a monthly column in the magazine.

TI Media (formerly IPC Magazines, IPC Media and Time Inc. UK) published the magazine until the May 2020, issue with Kelsey Media taking over the following issue after acquired the title from Future plc, the successor of TI Media. Hamilton, who had worked for World Soccer for 26 years, stepped down as editor after publishing the 60th anniversary edition in June 2020.

Other regular contributors have included Paul Gardner, with a focus on football in the United States; David Conn; Jonathan Wilson; Mark Gleeson on African football; Tim Vickery, Brian Homewood and Eric Weil on South American football.

item.title: Star Wars Dark Horse
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: Star Wars, presented on the cover as Star Wars featuring Indiana Jones, was a short-lived monthly comic series released in the United Kingdom in the early 1990s. First released in September 1992 (but dated October 1992 on the cover of the first issue) by Dark Horse Comics’ overseas subsidiary, Dark Horse International, the book reprinted […]
item.content:encoded:
Star Wars, presented on the cover as Star Wars featuring Indiana Jones, was a short-lived monthly comic series released in the United Kingdom in the early 1990s.

First released in September 1992 (but dated October 1992 on the cover of the first issue) by Dark Horse Comics’ overseas subsidiary, Dark Horse International, the book reprinted issues from the company’s Star Wars and Indiana Jones series.

The series was abruptly canceled with issue 10 in June 1993 which had just begun reprinting the first issues of Ulic Qel-Droma and the Beast Wars of Onderon from Tales of the Jedi and Indiana Jones: Thunder in the Orient.

The Dark Horse International checklist for its upcoming releases at the back of the tenth installment indicates that Star Wars 11 was to continue these storylines as well as begin reprinting The Serpent Masters. The checklist also refers to a “Dark Empire Technical Readout” feature by Tom Veitch and Cam Kennedy, possibly the Dark Empire endnotes, which was also promised for issue 10 but never came to pass.

Star Wars DH 01-03,05-10

Download

item.title: Robin2
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: I’ve made pictures from our walks through the neighborhood, Robin is beginning to be a wellknown bird allready, people come to me and begin to talk to her and asking me all sort of questions about her. She enjoys it as much as i do, when i place the strollcage on the table and open […]
item.content:encoded:
I’ve made pictures from our walks through the neighborhood, Robin is beginning to be a wellknown bird allready, people come to me and begin to talk to her and asking me all sort of questions about her.
She enjoys it as much as i do, when i place the strollcage on the table and open the door, it’s a matter of a few minutes and she climbs inside looking in a way “can we go now”. I never force her to go with me, there are day’s she won’t climb in the cage, even after waiting awhile, i don’t force her in and go outside by myself, but that happens very occiasionally, even birds can have a not so good day.

At the educational farm

At the skatepark

Waiting for the elevator

Inside the local church

In the local trainstation, i am planning to take her with the train also someday.

We didn’t do it

Into the wilderness

At the local butchershop

At the local fish stall, these boys always flutes to Robin and she calls back to them

I’ve made some popsicles with fruit for her

Watching football

Once a week i make a dish for her with all sorts of healthy goodies

Just hanging around

After a bathingsession

Taking a nap after all these activities
